Posts.Content: I had a mastectomy last year and since finishing chemo and radiotherapy the nipple on my remaining breast has started going in, so now it is completely inverted. I was full of anxiety and panic, but I saw my surgeon and he did an ultrasound scan on it and said it's just due to the ducts shortening and pulling the nipple in. He said it's fairly common in women as they get older and nothing to worry about. I've also had my first mammogram and that didn't detect anything either. Fingers crossed your wife will have something similar and it will just be a false alarm.

Posts.Title: Advice please-Mastectomy with lymph node clearance

Posts.Content: That's really interesting Jen. My surgery will be 3 weeks tomorrow too, so same day. Everything was done from the one incision. I asked about a reconstruction but the surgeon wasn't keen. He said it could take longer to heal and he wants me on chemo as soon as possible afterwards, but he has done what he could to make a reconstruction easier further down the track - or so he said. I ended up with 4 drains in total. I started with 2 - one from the centre of the breast area and one from the armpit end. The breast one came out on the second day, but on the third night the armpit one blocked up. It caused infection and a hematoma so I was on IV antibiotics and the surgeon removed the drain and attempted to shove a new one in through the same hole. That was very painful to experience and didn't work, so I had to go back to theatre and they put 2 new drains in. Possibly that is what is giving me more pain now - having that area interfered with twice in 4 days. I haven't been told anything about deodorant at all, so I've been carefully using a stick one avoiding getting near the incision at all. I found I was sweating a lot there when I was in the hospital as it was so warm all the time, and I couldn't lift my arm up properly to have air circulating. That combined with a reaction to the dressing gave me an armpit full of blisters, but they have settled down now I have no dressing on. My daughter works as a nurse in a short stay ward in an Australian hospital and she flew over, so she brought me a great long handled cotton bag that they use for mastectomy patients. They are sewed by volunteers and given free to patients - enough room for 2 drains easily, plus a little side pocket for a mobile phone! All the nurses at the hospital here admired it. She also brought me a moon-shaped cushion with an elastic strap across the pointy ends. It goes over my shoulder and protects the area so it was great for under the seatbelt when I was driven home from hospital. I haven't tried wearing a bra yet. I have one that I bought from the Breast Care nurse before surgery, but the area feels too sensitive yet. I'm not very big busted so it doesn't bother me and if I have a loose cardigan or jacket on I don't think my being lopsided is too noticeable. I do keep moving my shoulder as much as possible though, and today I had a go at driving for the first time. The doctor said it was up to me when I felt comfortable and it's only a short drive to our village shop so I decided to try. I managed ok, but I was quite tired and had to have a nap afterwards. Nice to make another milestone though! Dee

Posts.Content: Thanks for the encouragement Jen and Nix. I'm perservering with massaging and doing the exercises, and I find the more I do earlier in the day the better. It gets more painful as the day wears on and my movement gets more limited so I just concentrate on relaxing the area as much as I can then. I have a slight added complication in that I had melanoma surgery on the same arm 6 years ago and I have a long scar that curves around my forearm almost from my wrist to my elbow. The current pain reaches down to that scar and is making it feel tight and sore too. The lymphodema person that saw me in the hospital said I have to massage in stages going round the scar as fluid will be obstructed by it, so it's a bit of a performance. I have an appointment with a lymphodema clinic on Thursday so I'll get some more advice from them then. No idea yet when the chemo will start. I rang last Wednesday but they said they still hadn't had the results through from pathology. I think I'll call again around 3pm today and see if I can get an answer on when my appointment is likely to be. My daughter is booked to fly back to Australia on the 13th, but she doesn't want to go until she knows exactly what the pathology results showed and what my treatment will be from here in. Posts.Title: Chemo farts

Posts.Content: dalefarm Distraction therapy and physically not being able to see the drugs might help. Ask the nurses to cover the lines with a pillowcase or something. As former paediatric nurse you have to find ways of making things better for the patient. Talk to the nursing staff, as someone else has said they may have encountered a similar problem before. Please don't suffer in silence.Â  I had cannulas at first, then the PICC line. I can't bear to see things going into my body so the nurses always covered everything with a big loose dressing. Is that possible with a portacath? I also told the nurses not to talk about what they were doing as I didn't want to know. The "Sharp Scratch" was the only comment I would allow. The district nurses learnt to hide the vials of blood away under something after doing my blood tests too as I didn't want to see them. Is there anything you can take to do that would be a treat for you? A film you've always wanted to watch but didn't get time for? Crosswords or puzzles that you would enjoy doing and would take your mind off it? I'm actually a mad keen amateur linguist, so I took my tablet and did language revision, so I saw my chemo sessions as an opportunity to treat myself to something I enjoyed. Is there something you could do that would be the same?
Posts.Title: Psychological revulsion towards intravenous drugs

Posts.Content: Lacomtekp Re: the teeth. My dentist's wife had had breast cancer. When I lost half the outside of a tooth last month, I took it to show him as my husband had an appointment. Up until then I had just been losing little bits and pieces. He was in no doubt that chemo drugs may have contributed. I have six teeth which need rebuilding. I have an appointment next week for an estimate as I live in a place where dental treatment isn't covered. I think its going be too expensive for me. Dentist says its not the centre or roots, they are still strong. Just the enamel. I'm really interested that several of you are getting the same problem. There has to be a connection, doesn't there? It's starting to make sense to me now! Since I started chemo I had a piece fall off a crown, which the dentist smoothed off, then an abcess under a molar which had to be extracted, then a chunk came off another tooth which will need refilling and rebuilding, then the remaining part of the crown broke and came off in two pieces. Luckily the crown is covered under a 5-year warrantee, so at least I'll get that done again for nothing. The dentist says I'm grinding my teeth and that he's never seen that type of crown break before. I don't know if I've always ground my teeth or if it's something brought on by the chemo, but I'll be watching the enamel like a hawk now!

Posts.Content: Hi Kerry, I had a mastectomy June last year, then chemo and I'm almost finished the Herceptin injections. It was suggested to me that I was borderline for benefitting from Tamoxifen but if I was happy to try it, then that's what they recommended. If I got side effects that were bothering me I could stop taking it. I thought about it and chatted to a good friend who had a mastectomy 10 years ago and is still taking Tamoxifen by choice. She said she considers it her little life insurance pill that she takes each night, and I liked that way of looking at it so, even though I hate taking regular medication, I decided to give it a try. I've been taking it since about March now and the only side effect I have is that I sometimes wake up feeling hot in the night or first thing in the morning. I can't say much about appetite as I've always had a good appetite despite being slim. I did put 5 kgs on during chemo, but lost it again despite being on Tamoxifen so it doesn't always cause weight gain. I would suggest you give it a try and see how you go. One thing I do is to write the initials of the days of the week on the back of each bubble containing the tablet in the pack. I'm not sure about other brands but the one I have doesn't have any markings and I want to make sure I take one every day. Best wishes,

Posts.Content: This same question has just been discussed in the September Chemo Club thread, so you may find some answers there that will help you. This was posted by lynnwad I lost little or no hair cold capping & I had a tingly sensitive scalp also aching like I had tied my pigtail too tight I took paracetamol & it eased it. Remember to always brush it every day or y'll get matting. Get a wet brush Amazon Â£5 best thing I ever bought Also Argan oil massage into scalp & brush thru & leave on overnight & wash next day. Posts.Title: Picc line for chemo

Posts.Content: One thing I found important was to know how to check your own wound for any signs of change. You can ask the nurses to show you before you leave the hospital, or just yourself gently feel around the wound so you get used to what it feels like and you can detect any changes, e.g. lumps or swellings that weren't there before. Usually a district nurse will come and see you once a day and check your drain, if you're usually discharged with one still in, but you don't want to wait 24 hours if you develop signs of infection. If you know what is normal for you, then you can act quickly if you detect something different. If you need to see a doctor, or get back to the hospital urgently, let your friends know that you may need to call them in the middle of the night - just in case! Keep in touch here so we know you're ok.

Posts.Content: Hi Karakeys, I know exactly how you feel. I was diagnosed in May, had a mastectomy in June and have just had my first chemo treatment. I still find it very hard to believe this is actually happening, and at times I want to just say "OK, that's enough now. I'll just forget about it and go back to how I was", but I know that's not possible. It's really weird if you don't feel ill at all but you have to subject yourself to treatment that makes you feel ill. I struggle to get my head around it at times. I'm also self-employed. I do some work from home and I'm trying to keep that up, but my income is plummeting. The finance advice people are great, so ask for whatever help you can get. I've been told I have to live off my savings until I bring them down to a certain point, then I'll be able to get some sickness support. I also live alone with my daughter and son both in Australia. But this forum is the place to be. Before I had my first chemo treatment I read all the discussions on here and got myself prepared. I won't say I'm handling it really well as I hate feeling ill, and I don't like what is being done to me, but I try to keep focusing on the end. There is no choice and it will pass. Sending you a big hug!

Posts.Title: Cording 15 months after surgery!

Posts.Content: I was feeling like I was top of things - mastectomy and node clearance June last year, then chemo, then radiotherapy, now concentrate on getting my life back. I had some small issues with lymphoedema in my affected arm, but that seemed to be under control with twice-daily exercises and a sleeve. But something has gone wrong. I woke up Weds morning with a painful tight wire stretching down from my armpit to my wrist, and a puffy forearm. I tried putting the sleeve on but it was really painful and made my hand swell up so I took it off. I called the lymphoedema specialist and she said it is unusual but it sounds like I have cording - 15 months after surgery! She said to leave the sleeve off for now, but to take pain relief then massage down the length of the cord with my finger tips. I'm trying to do it, but I have a long scar on my forearm from when I had melanoma surgery 7 years ago, and it really hurts if I massage anywhere near that. I'm wondering if that scar is actually interfering with the lymph drainage, though I don't know if that's even a possibility. I'll be getting an appointment in the post to see the lymphoedema specialist, but I feel so despondent and fed up with the whole thing today. When does it ever end?

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm having Carboplatin together with Docetaxel. I have the Docetaxel first which takes an hour, then the Carboplatin for another hour. To be honest I don't know a lot about it. I haven't really gone into it at all, just accepted what the oncologist said. I'm seeing her again next Wednesday, so now that I've had 2 cycles and I'm a bit more out of the shock of it all I'm going to ask more and see exactly what it's targeting. All I've noticed is that it affects my veins more than the Docetaxel. I'm just having it through a cannula and I notice that when the Carboplatin starts I get intermittent pulses of pain up my vein. They give me a warm sleeve to put over it and warm my arm up and that helps so I can bear it. The last thing I want is for them to move the cannula as I hate the things, but I'm really happy coming home with nothing to worry about as it just gets removed at the end of the session and that's it for 3 weeks. I only had my second cycle on Thursday and I've reacted completely differently this time. The first cycle I was all hyped up, everything swirling around inside me and feeling agitated. This time I'm like a zombie - sleeping a lot, very relaxed inside and no energy. But as I'm having Herceptin injections as well, I can't really say which drug is doing what. If the oncologist explains more about the Carboplatin next week I'll post here. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Starting Carboplatin

Posts.Content: Hi all, My second cycle of Docetaxel and Carboplatin caused a reaction totally the opposite to the first cycle. First time round I was very agitated inside, unable to sleep properly for about 10 days, lots of cramps and constipation followed by a couple of days of diarrhoea. This time round I was zonked out! Totally, completely relaxed inside with no energy and just sleeping really deeply, waking for a bit to eat, then sleeping again. That lasted from Thursday through to Tuesday morning when I woke up feeling relatively normal. The Chemo Unit gave me a mild laxative to take which I just drank with each meal and I had no digestive issues at all. I also found when I was awake that I could drink a lot more water, so that probably helped too. I was so lacking in energy on Sunday that I was thinking "If this is cumulative how on earth will I move a muscle when I get near the end?" but I feel so much better now I'm really happy. So yesterday I had a meeting with my oncologist, and I must say I think I hit the jackpot with her. She is brilliant - not only a really nice person, but she answers all my questions and explains everything in detail if that's what I want. I asked why the different drugs and what they do exactly. She said that they tackle different stages of the regeneration of cancer cells. The Carboplatin goes to the DNA and messes with the structure of it so that when the cell tries to replicate it doesn't have the right information and can't do it successfully. The Docetaxel acts on a later stage, so if the cell has got itself ready to replicate successfully, the Docetaxel interferes with the splitting apart process so it can't divide properly. I found that really interesting, and knowing that helps me to appreciate what is going into me when I have the chemo sessions and to feel really positive about what it's doing. So, it's 2 weeks of building myself back up ready for the next round. My blood count was slightly low from the test 2 days before, but was up enough by the day of the chemo, thank goodness. The onco said I'm a bit anaemic already, which didn't surprise me as I always have low iron levels, so it's "eat lots of iron-rich food" now to avoid having an infusion down the track. I have the runny, slightly bleeding, nose again this time, but not quite as bad as the first, so I try not to blow it if possible. Cheers all!

Posts.Content: I've had two sessions now with the cold cap. I don't have a problem with the cold on my head, though I did find I need a lot of padding across the back of my shoulders as the tube goes across them down to the machine and that's cold too. I'm only small as well. They tried the small size cap but it didn't cover enough of my head, so they went for the medium with the covering straps pulled really tight. It must have been looser the first time though as I could still get my glasses on. The second time there was no way I could push them under the cap to get them behind my ears, so that was frustrating as I couldn't read or do any colouring for the entire time it was on. Luckily I could push earbuds through small gaps in the strapping and listen to podcasts, so I had to content myself with that. But as I head towards my 3rd session I'm wondering whether it's actually worth it for me. My hair was quite thick and curly but so much has come out. I don't have any bald patches. It's just coming out evenly all over. I try to just sort of plump it up with my fingers instead of combing it and I'm only washing it once a week with a very mild shampoo, but in the morning it's all over my pillow and there is hair all over the house. I'm seriously considering giving up, getting my head shaved, and wearing turbans until it grows back. The thought is more upsetting than I had expected. The logical part of me says it will grow back so what are you worried about, but emotionally I don't think I've really accepted that I have cancer and seeing myself so different will perhaps hit home. I hope others are having more success than I am. They do say that it seems to be more effective for some than others.

Posts.Title: In a right tizz now!

Posts.Content: People's experiences are different, but in my case I had no detectable lumps or anything. I went for the routine mammogram and got called for "further tests". I was told at that point that there was an area of calcification in my breast that was "concerning" and I needed to have biopsies done to determine exactly what it was. I remember thinking stupid calcium! I had been diagnosed with osteoporisis 2 months earlier and I wondered what the calcium was doing in my breast instead of in my bones where it belonged! It did turn out to be breast cancer though and I ended up with a mastectomy. The oncologist explained that when cells die they can leave traces of calcium, and when you have cancer that can speed up the turn over of cells, so that's why it can show up as calcium in scans. I know it's not always the case though. Sometimes it's something quite innocent. I sincerely hope that's the situation for your friend, but knowing how I felt at the time, I'm glad your friend has someone like you looking out for her!
Posts.Title: Calcium in breast

Posts.Content: I'm keeping a diary now. I didn't start it right at the beginning. I thought about it, but I couldn't face it enough to write it down. It made it too real somehow. So I wrote nothing about the mastectomy and my time in hospital, which I found quite traumatic and I still have difficulty thinking about. Since I started chemo though I started writing, initially prompted by thinking that I should probably record my temperature each day. I do that first thing in the morning and last thing at night, just to be sure! That has helped me realise what is a normal variation for me, so I will recognise if something is going astray. I do find it helps to think back over the day and realise that even on my tired days I've managed to accomplish something and feel happy about that. I note anything that might be a side effect too, so I can look back before my next onco appointment and make sure I cover everything. As for reading it in the future, probably not. I kept a diary during some very turbulent years when I was younger then burnt it afterwards as I didn't want to look back. I might not burn this one, but I doubt I will want to read it again.

She said that she may have to change strategy depending on the result, and I do respect her for that, even if it is making me anxious. I asked the Oncology nurse what 'change strategy' actually meant, just different drugs? At first she seemed reluctant to clarify and just repeated 'change strategy', then she said 'Yes, yes, different drugs' but there was something about the way she said it that didn't really convince me. I'm not sure if she just didn't know or if there was something she didn't want to tell me. Or maybe I'm just getting so worked up about it all I'm getting paranoid. I've decided to just go for a walk this afternoon and not think about it for a while. If I let myself calm down and give myself time to think through the issues, I'll write them down then decide what to do. Thanks so much for trying to help me. I have my parents and my brother staying nearby at the moment but like others on here I find it very hard to talk to them. My dad has been having monthly injections for a medical condition which my mother tells everyone are 'chemo' injections. They are definitely NOT, but it means that if I mention anything about chemo I just get a long story of how my dad is dealing with his "chemo". It makes me so angry as they just dismiss my situation and think it's the same as my dad's, but I just have to take a deep breath and let it wash over me. Right - out for a walk and some fresh air!
Posts.Title: Lymph nodes in the mesentery

Posts.Content: Hi Karen, I just saw this before I headed out for a walk. Thank you so much for the information! It does help me a lot to at least know what is ahead of me, and as you say, if that gives me the all clear it will be fantastic news! I hope it was all fine for you too! Merci beaucoup!
Posts.Title: Lymph nodes in the mesentery

Posts.Content: I went to my first appointment with my oncologist yesterday. She was extremely thorough, going back through everything with me right from the biopsy results to make sure I understood, and I could ask as many questions as I wanted. Then she gave me a shock. My supposedly clear CAT scan of my lungs and liver had a comment on it from the radiologist to say that they detected lymph nodes in the mesentery - an area near the top of my intestine - but they weren't noted as enlarged. The oncologist said it was most probably because I'm quite thin, so they showed up in me where they wouldn't normally, but she was going to raise the question with the radiologist in their team meeting today. She called me afterwards to say that in fact the lymph nodes are slightly enlarged and she has some concern about that, so now I have to have a CT PET scan to find out what's going on. I'd had a call from the Chemo Unit saying that I could go for my pre-assessment next Thursday, and my first chemo session the following Monday (22nd), but now the oncologist says I can still go for the pre-assessment as long as I'm not busy with the PET scan that day, but the start of the chemo is on hold until she gets the result of the PET scan and knows what we are dealing with. I was already feeling stressed as they told me the closest Chemo Unit doesn't handle portacaths and they want me to TRY with a cannula before they consider a PICC line or Hickman line. They sent me for a MUGA heart check after that and I cried my way through a cannula insertion for that procedure. The nurse that did that said she couldn't see me coping with one for chemo. It's hard enough having to go through all this stuff. If something's available that can make it a bit easier, why can't I have it? So has anyone else had to have this PET scan for lymph nodes in the mesentery?
Posts.Title: Lymph nodes in the mesentery

Posts.Content: Thanks Carolyn, I'm just getting so anxious about how much time is going by. I was diagnosed in May, mastectomy on June 13th, it's now almost 2 months later and I haven't started on chemo yet. I've had a phone call to say that they can't fit me in for a PET scan until the week starting the 22nd, so it's getting longer and longer. They've told me to still go for my pre-assessment next Thursday, but I almost wonder what's the point ... unless I can convince them about the portacath. It would give more time to get it fitted ready! The main excuse was that they aren't used to doing them and they don't have a supply of the special needles - well, get a bit of training and a supply of needles in! That's no reason not to offer something to patients, surely! How different a technique can it be? If they can cope with PICC lines and Hickman lines, it can't be a huge training exercise to learn to cope with a portacath.
